ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I continued my learning in introductory Chinese through reading comprehension, listening, speaking, and writing exercises. I also learned more specific vocabulary that would be useful within a real-world setting.
Beginner-intermediate Chinese including characters, grammar, speaking, presentation, and short-passage writing.

I now feel confident speaking, reading, and writing material up to L2. I especially feel that my listening skills have improved greatly, and I can understand almost all of what my professor, Zhang lao shi, says in class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very fast pace which forced you to learn the material
This course was intense. But it is good that way.

This was always a very interactive class, but I think that that is very professor-dependent. It was very fun to get to know my classmates and work closely with them on a daily basis. 

The only real weakness with the way that Chinese is taught at Yale is the pacing at times: sometimes, we will take extra time to review certain grammar topics, potentially to the detriment of solidifying knowledge in other areas. However, this seemed to rarely happen.

This course has a pretty high workload, which makes it difficult to enjoy at times. Additionally, not all TFs are equally helpful, so students may or may not receive the extra support during section. I also think there is not enough instruction on writing characters (I.e. stroke by stroke instruction) The strength is that students finish this course with a much higher level of Chinese skills.

Each class is very engaging with student participation in speaking, homework, and presentations.
We could replace oral presentations and memorization to more consistent writing practice and application of grammar into practical speaking practice. Tutoring sessions are not very helpful, which can be replaced with speaking/listening practice rather than reviewing grammar.

I believe that the emphasis on writing characters has derailed from other aspects of learning Chinese. I understand that it is important in order to learn the characters and I think daily dictation is important, but I feel that dictations on the tests make it so I spend so much time learning to write the characters, a skill I will likely not need in the real world, that I can't spend as much time on the rest of the material. I also think tutorials should be structured differently; I find that I don't learn anything during tutorials. It just feels like doing an extra piece of homework, when I think it would be much more useful to spend the time speaking with our TAs, practicing oral questions and that kind of thing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, learning a new language is very rewarding
Yes. Zhang lao shi is a gem of teacher. Great person and educator.
Yes! the class atmosphere is great and the professors are really supportive

I would definitely recommend this course. I am a bit biased (as I enjoy taking language classes for fun), but I think that the Chinese department at Yale is something that any student remotely interested in learning languages should take advantage of while they are here.
Yes, this is a great course that gives you a strong foundation in Chinese in preparation for higher level courses.
I would definitely recommend this course to other students. I feel like I've learned a great deal in only two semesters.
